1 Einführung Um ein neues Chapter zu erstellen, legt man eine neue Rmd Datei in RStudio an (Datei -> Neu -> RMarkdown). Der Dateiname sollte durchnummeriert sein (vgl. 02-sample-chapter.Rmd). Den YAML Header (alles zwischen ---) kann man löschen. Wichtig ist, dass das Dokument mit einer Markdown Überschrift beginnt: # My Chapter Markdown provides an easy way to make standard types of formatted text, like italics bold code links etc. Ein Zitat kann man so machen: this is a quote. (A very cool person) 1.1 Citations You can write citations, too. For example, we are using the bookdown package in this sample book, which was built on top of R Markdown and knitr (Xie 2015). We can also cite R Packages, e.g. knitr (Xie 2020) or: Rmarkdown is a package by Allaire et al. (2020) Center for Data Science and Public Policy (2018) 1.2 Tables 1.2.1 kable Table 1.1: Datenreifegrad sozialer Organisationen Thema Unzureichend Ausreichend Fortgeschritten Ausgezeichnet Zugang Nur in der Anwendung verfügbar, in der die Daten erhoben werden Daten können in einfachen Formaten (z.B. You can also use R to include images. One advantage is that we can use the chunk label for crossreferencing. For that to work, we need to provide a caption to the figure by using the chunk option fig.cap. knitr::include_graphics("resources/images/logo.png") Figure 1.1: A caption control width / height using different chunk options knitr::include_graphics("resources/images/logo.png") knitr::include_graphics("resources/images/logo.png") plot(cars$speed) Figure 1.2: a plot from the cars dataset 1.4 Cross-referencing Goes to title logo 0.1 goes to first small logo 1.1 goes to cars plot 1.2 goes to kable table 1.1 reference another section : 1, you can also hyperlink a section: Read more about it in the intro section. 3 Sample Chapter 3.1 R Markdown 3.2 Including Plots

3 Sample Chapter 3.1 R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.:19.0 3rd Qu.: 56.00 ## Max. :25.0 Max. :120.00 3.2 Including Plots You can also embed plots, for example: Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

References Allaire, JJ, Yihui Xie, Jonathan McPherson, Javier Luraschi, Kevin Ushey, Aron Atkins, Hadley Wickham, Joe Cheng, Winston Chang, and Richard Iannone. 2020. Rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rmarkdown. Center for Data Science and Public Policy, University of Chicago. 2018. “Data Maturity Framework.” Data Maturity Framework. http://www.datasciencepublicpolicy.org/home/resources/datamaturity/. Xie, Yihui. 2015. Dynamic Documents with R and Knitr. 2nd ed. Boca Raton, Florida: Chapman; Hall/CRC. http://yihui.name/knitr/. ———. 2020. Knitr: A General-Purpose Package for Dynamic Report Generation in R. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=knitr.
